Induction of ROS and cytotoxicity has been similarly demonstrated in bronchial epithelial and alveolar cell modeling of titanium dioxide, gold, palladium, lead halide perovskite, iron, and manganese [11, 30, 37, 55, 93–95, 99, 100]. Induction of apoptosis in alveolar cells is demonstratable with model exposures to zinc, nickel, and tungsten carbide cobalt NPs [92, 101, 102]. Titanium dioxide is present as a ubiquitous whitening pigment and is widely used in catalytic and photocatalytic applications such as water and air filtration and self-cleaning surfaces. Models of respiratory toxicity from titanium dioxide have been conflicting, with several studies failing to demonstrate cytotoxicity or micronuclei genotoxicity markers at varying concentrations and in various cells lines [43, 74, 103, 104]. However, titanium dioxide exposed alveolar and bronchial models have shown altered expression of histone deacetylase 9, which is an epigenetic modifier, and that production of ROS, cytotoxicity, glutathione production, and DNA double strand breaks are influenced by titanium dioxide agglomeration, the presence of a more toxic nanofiber rather than nanoparticle, or the predominance of the anatase or rutile structure [30, 99, 105–107]. Interactions with the pulmonary surfactant is a critical factor, as components like DPPC have been shown to coat silver nanoparticles, improving their dispersion and delaying the release of toxic ions [108]. Shotgun proteomics, a high-throughput mass-spectrometry technique that identifies and quantifies proteins from complex mixtures, have identified one underlying mechanism as the dysregulation of protein phosphorylation sites, with subsequent impact on DNA repair and cell cycle regulation, autophagy and cytoskeletal structure and dynamics, cellular transport, RNA dynamics, with a central role of p53 [65]. Epithelial barrier integrity, as in studies of genotoxicity, represents a central determinant of NP behavior in vitro, shaping both apparent toxicity and the way experimental results are extrapolated to human risk. Barrier status influences not only particle uptake and translocation but also the interpretation of downstream effects such as inflammation, oxidative stress, and cell viability. Modern respiratory models increasingly emphasize this point through advanced in vitro systems that recapitulate the ALI, allowing aerosolized nanometal exposures to occur under physiologically relevant conditions [74, 109–111]. These systems demonstrate that deposition dynamics, dissolution, and ionic transformation vary substantially from submerged monolayer cultures, leading to lower apparent toxicity at realistic doses. Methodological refinements, including electrostatic deposition, dynamic flow exposure, and barrier maturation protocols, have enabled closer approximation to in vivo airway deposition while highlighting the role of serum and protein coronas in modulating NP reactivity [112, 113]. Multiparametric approaches have further clarified that protein adsorption and cytokine binding can confound apparent inflammatory outcomes in submerged assays, reinforcing the need for integrated evaluation of intracellular, secreted, and transcriptional endpoints [114]. Collectively, these studies mark a shift from simplified cytotoxicity assays toward barrier-competent reagents that can distinguish direct nanomaterial effects from secondary phenomena related to barrier disruption or ion-mediated stress. With these modeling advances established, current research has turned toward the consequences of barrier loss itself, examining how disruption of tight and adherens junctions alters respiratory permeability and permits NP translocation into systemic circulation and target organs. Loss of barrier integrity in this manners, independent of cytotoxicity and altered gene expression, has been demonstrated with silver and tungsten NPs as well as titanium dioxide [103, 115, 116]. Notably, the loss of cell membrane integrity induced by nano zero-valent iron and zinc oxide NPs occurs via inflammatory responses in endothelial cells and is concurrent with production of ROS, cytotoxicity, and cytokine signaling [89, 117, 118]. Disruption of tight junctions is associated with multiple atopic and inflammatory disease states, such as asthma, atopic dermatitis, and inflammatory bowel disease [115]. However, loss of epithelial barrier integrity is not a consistent finding across models; one 3D bronchial epithelial model (Calu-3) for silver NPs did not disrupt epithelial barriers or induce cytotoxicity [119]. These advances redefine respiratory nanotoxicology by shifting attention from isolated cytotoxic endpoints to barrier-dependent mechanisms of injury and repair. Another critical determinant of respiratory response is the pulmonary surfactant layer that lines the alveoli and airways. This lipid–protein interface governs NP dispersion, dissolution, and cellular contact, yet its influence on toxicity remains context dependent. Natural surfactant mixtures can attenuate silver NP cytotoxicity by limiting ionic release [120], whereas other formulations fail to suppress the oxidative or inflammatory effects of silver nanowires [121]. In some cases, single surfactant components such as DPPC even exacerbate oxidative stress and cytokine signaling [122]. For zinc oxide nanowires, surfactant coatings delayed early cell death but increased uptake and delayed toxicity [123]. These findings illustrate that pulmonary surfactant interactions are a key but variable modifier of NP behavior, and that faithfully incorporating the biochemical and biophysical complexity of this interface into advanced airway models remains a continuing methodological limitation in respiratory nanotoxicology. Epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a cellular program in which epithelial cells lose polarity and adhesion, acquiring migratory and fibroblast-like traits central to fibrosis and remodeling. NP exposure can induce EMT through oxidative stress and DNA damage–mediated activation of the 8-oxoguanine DNA glycosylase 1 base-excision repair pathway [124]. Palladium NPs from catalytic converters and lead perovskite both trigger EMT in bronchial epithelial cells via TGF-β1 signaling, implicating EMT dysregulation in fibrotic and structural lung disease [55, 100]. Uncoated cerium oxide NPs, over 80% internalized by lung epithelium within 24 h, directly stimulate collagen synthesis and fibroblastic nodule formation in human lung fibroblasts-effects mitigated by silica coating as a safety-by-design measure [125, 126]. Titanium- and iron-based cosmetic aerosols deposit ultrafine particles in tracheobronchial regions, where exposure produces greater oxidative stress and accumulation of 8-oxoguanine DNA lesions than equivalent doses of pristine titanium or iron NPs [124]. Beyond epithelial effects, zinc oxide and copper oxide NPs diminish airway smooth-muscle contractility through non-ROS biomechanical mechanisms [127], suggesting a broader role of nanometal exposure in respiratory dysfunction. Considered in context, these findings indicate that NP toxicity in the respiratory tract arises less from size alone than from persistent oxidative and signaling disruptions that reprogram both epithelial and mesenchymal compartments.

## Exposure measurement
Understanding NP toxicity requires accounting for the exposure phase, particle chemistry, and realistic dosing. As previously discussed, most in vitro studies utilize submerged cell cultures; however, these systems do not entirely replicate the manner in which aerosols interact with airway surfaces. Comparisons under equivalent mass doses show that zinc oxide NPs delivered as aerosols produce earlier oxidative and inflammatory responses than suspensions, with peak effects at four hours instead of twenty-four, but the total response magnitude later converges, indicating that liquid systems delay but do not prevent cellular injury [128]. Chemical transformations in air further influence toxicity: magnetite NPs coated by acidic or organic films release more soluble iron and provoke stronger oxidative and cytokine responses than uncoated forms [129]. Atmospheric processing, not only composition or size, determines biological activity. Controlled human inhalation studies define the boundary between mechanistic data and occupational exposure. Inhalation of 0.5 mg/m³ zinc oxide produced no measurable systemic or respiratory effects [130]. Subsequent work demonstrated a concentration-dependent inflammatory response across 0.5–2 mg/m³ nano-ZnO, with significant increases in neutrophils and acute-phase proteins at and above 1 mg/m³, defining the lower threshold for transient systemic effects [131]. A later comparison at 2 mg/m³ under exertion showed similar responses for nano- and micro-ZnO, with slightly higher values for the latter due to greater deposition efficiency rather than particle size toxicity [132]. Across these investigations, toxicity scaled primarily with deposited mass and ionic dissolution rather than nominal particle size. Simulations of workplace aerosols demonstrate that biologically relevant cellular doses are orders of magnitude lower than those typically applied in in vitro toxicology studies [12]. These modeling approaches define the concentration range within which experimental data can be meaningfully compared to human exposure scenarios. Field measurements complement this framework by confirming that respirable NPs are generated under ordinary use conditions. For example, commercial spray products emitting titanium dioxide can transiently exceed recommended exposure limits during brief applications [13]. Broader assessments show that indoor nanomaterial measurements often capture mixed emissions from combustion sources and process aerosols rather than the engineered product itself [14]. These findings link modeled exposure potential with real-world aerosol occurrence, showing that accurate interpretation of NP toxicity requires consideration of realistic dose levels and environmental context, as demonstrated in occupational settings such as welding and firearm exposure. While metal fume fever has been recognized for decades [133], the contribution of nano-sized particulate matter is now being described. Lung-tissue analysis of professional welders identified iron, manganese, and chromium oxide NPs within macrophages and fibrotic regions, linking chronic exposure to persistent inflammation [134]. Modeled airflow studies indicate that only about 1% of welding-fume agglomerates deposit in the olfactory mucosa, but morphology, long chains versus compact clusters, strongly influences this fraction [135]. Thus, particle geometry contributes to deposition and potential for systemic translocation. Because manganese constitutes a major component of many welding aerosols, these deposition patterns have important implications for neurotoxicity, with elevated blood manganese levels linked to basal ganglia hyperintensity on MRI and reduced working-memory performance in exposed workers even at routine exposure levels [136, 137]. Controlled exposure of apprentice welders to tungsten inert gas fumes demonstrated transient oxidative stress, with elevated hydrogen peroxide and 8-hydroxy-2′-deoxyguanosine in plasma and urine three hours post-exposure [138]. Comparable findings in active stainless-steel welders showed chromium and nickel in exhaled breath condensate correlated with oxidative biomarkers [139]. Quantitative exposure measurements reinforce this relevance. Comparative monitoring of carbon-steel and aluminum welding revealed alveolar-deposited surface areas exceeding tens of thousands of µm²/cm³, demonstrating that even low-fume processes emit respirable ultrafine particles [140]. This is convergent evidence that welding aerosols contribute to measurable biological stress, with deposition behavior, surface area, and transition-metal content as key determinants of effect. Military facilities and indoor firing ranges generate complex aerosols composed of ultrafine metals and combustion gases. Characterization of shooting-range air shows that it contains respirable lead and antimony particles with high alveolar deposition potential [81]. Replacement of lead-based ammunition with alternative compositions reduces classical toxicants but introduces copper, zinc, manganese, and boron NPs, shifting rather than removing risk [81]. Experimental studies using collected firearm particles demonstrate oxidative stress and cytokine release in lung epithelial cultures, with highest toxicity from copper- and zinc-rich emissions [83]. ALI exposures to freshly generated firearm discharge confirm that these aerosols reduce cell viability and induce IL-8 signaling, with rifle fire producing greater effects than handguns [141]. Controlled exposures of ALI cultures to fumes from steel-core ammunition show similar findings, including genotoxicity linked to transition-metal and gas co-pollutant mixtures [82]. Human monitoring extends these observations. Repeated occupational exposure among firearm instructors is associated with oxidative-stress biomarkers and elevated urinary copper despite airborne metal levels below current limits [142]. Studies in police instructors exposed to similar ultrafine particle environments showed small, non-significant increases in inflammatory and endothelial markers, suggesting possible early biological responses that warrant continued investigation [143]. That said, while these studies suggest only mild or subclinical biological responses, the absence of pronounced nanometal toxicity should not be interpreted as evidence of safety, since firing-range personnel commonly exhibit elevated blood lead levels consistent with ongoing cumulative metal exposure [144–146].

## Discussion
What has been consistently demonstrated, across varying cell models, and organ-systems, is that the specific toxicity profile and intensity are dependent not only on the elemental composition of the NP, but also on the NP’s physicochemical characteristics. Yet, the chemical itself can be a key factor, such as when comparing the minimal inflammatory potential of barium sulfate compared to zinc oxide [99, 147]. For a given material like titanium dioxide, specific features such as primary particle size, crystal structure, and agglomeration state can significantly impact its demonstrable toxic effects [28]. It is also noteworthy that even previously considered non-toxic NPs may demonstrate toxic effect in the right circumstances: cerium(IV) oxide NPs did not exhibit any toxic effect by itself, but when zinc oxides were combined with cerium(IV) oxide, cytotoxic effects were observed, and IL-8 and ROS generation were higher when zinc oxide NPs were combined with CeO2 NPs, compared to ZnO alone [89]. The mechanism by which this potentiation of toxicity occurs in the presence of individually non-toxic cerium(IV) oxide is unclear, but may be due to changes in the oxidation state in the presence of zinc oxide [89]. These cell models underscore a critical point: the toxicity of a given NP can be significantly altered by its physicochemical state or by interactions with other metals, chemicals, or organic matter, warranting continued investigation even for materials presumed to be inert. Cell-based and in vitro models comprise the vast majority of extant literature for the toxicologic effects of metal-containing NPs in human organ systems. Any assessment of the existing body of literature must inherently acknowledge the limitations of such models to translate into clinically relevant toxicant-mediated end-organ effects or toxicant-related disease pathogenesis. For example, in vitro hemolysis induced from washed human erythrocytes exposed to titanium dioxide NPs would not imply an expectation for intravascular hemolysis in vivo among consumers exposed to TiO2 NPs from home sunscreen application given the specific limitation of the model to mimic real-world exposure conditions; i.e., the presence of human plasma which would be expected to abolish the effect [54]. Further limitations include an inconsistent cross-study model design, with some studies using an ALI to expose cells to NPs and others using a method for a submerged interface for NP exposures to cells. One ALI model using aerosol exposure chambers, which are self-contained cell culture systems that allow direct exposure to nanoparticles or other aerosols, demonstrated a greater increase in cytotoxicity and a larger reduction in cell viability for M4 rifle fumes compared to the M9 pistol, in A549 alveolar cells exposed to particulate iron-, nickel-, and copper-containing fumes generated directly from firing chambers [141]. ALI models such as this are considered superior in their ability to replicate in vitro conditions that more closely represent in vivo tissue–toxicant exposures, but reproducibility and experimental technique remain non-uniform across studies. The continued development and standardization of these models are likely to define the future of toxicologic research on nanoparticles [141]. However, the use of in vitro modelling holds advantages in allowing the elucidation of mechanistic cellular-based toxicities, and to avoid the obvious ethical quandaries of human-exposure implementation for toxicant NPs of interest. Furthermore, in vitro modelling tends to allow researchers to isolate individual NPs to identify their independent toxic profile, whereas an in vivo exposure model would tend to reflect end-organ toxicities from multiple simultaneous exposures. In a real-world occupational chemical characterization model in which shipyard abrasion and spray painting emissions were characterized for nanometal emissions (20 to 110 nm), the metal aerosol composition consisted of scandium, vanadium, chromium, cobalt, nickel, copper, rubidium, niobium, and cesium [86], and similarly, studies on consumer spray products have shown they can also be a source of exposure, generating respirable aerosols containing NPs such as titanium dioxide [13]. Upon exposure to these spray-painting aerosols, the majority composition described as copper and vanadium NPs, human alveolar cells (A549) demonstrated cytotoxicity, production of ROS, and increases in micronuclei frequency, indicating genotoxicity. Given the high prevalence of nanotechnologies in industry, commerce, and domestic use, a continued, systematic approach that couples chemical composition studies of mixed aerosol, dermal, and enteral metal-containing nanoparticle hazards with in vitro cellular analyses is essential for identifying disease states of interest and guiding future clinical research and monitoring. Where data are inconsistent in demonstrating NP-mediated tissue toxicity, such as with TiO2 inhalational exposure, it would suggest that an opportunity in future study would be for greater consistency of modelling between studies in order to enhance reproducibility of effects and instill greater confidence in interpretation of results [74, 103, 104, 113]. There is a continued need for studies in compositional analysis of environmental, occupational, and domestic exposures to NPs, especially as it is used in exposure-risk assessment models that couple with cellular toxicity modelling based on those toxicant exposures. Though certain nanometals such as silver NPs carry published recommended exposure limits from National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), other NPs with well described cellular toxicity such as zinc oxide NPs are not yet specifically addressed, and even with silver NPs, a computational fluid dynamics model of a short-term inhalation of 10 µg AgNP/m3, based on an exposure on NIOSH exposure limits for silver NPs yielded a blood-silver accumulation of 0.46 to 64 mg per year, which does exceed the lowest adverse effect level of 25 mg for an adult male [148]. In physiology based lung model using probabilistic risk assessment, the risk of titanium dioxide sprays in commercial spray sunscreen suggested that that application of sunscreen sprays poses no significant health risk; however, authors noted that sprays were only pressed twice within a certain period and that frequency of application is likely to be higher in consumer use according to guidelines on the product labels [149]. The burden and continued need for reassessment of risk will only continue to grow as these nanometals become ever more ubiquitous in daily life. Special emphasis should be made to identify readily obtainable biomarkers for significant NP, such as C-reactive protein or interferon gamma in nasal secretions, which correlate with exposure to ultrafine zinc and copper-containing welding fumes [150]. Once identified, such biomarkers could enable population-level monitoring to better correlate exposure with disease incidence. Titanium dioxide, the most widespread metal-containing nanoparticle in consumer and industrial products, exemplifies the need for accessible biomonitoring and ongoing reassessment of health risk as evidence accumulates linking epithelial barrier dysfunction to respiratory outcomes, including atopic and asthma-spectrum disease. This review has several limitations inherent to its scope and design. The search was limited to the PubMed database and English-language publications, which likely excluded relevant studies indexed elsewhere or reported in other languages. The review period was restricted to the past two decades, reflecting the era in which “nanoparticle” terminology and characterization became standardized; earlier ultrafine-particle studies may therefore contain relevant findings that were not captured. No formal critical appraisal of study quality was conducted due to the absence of any established framework specific to nanometal toxicology. Finally, given the heterogeneity of in vitro models and exposure systems, reproducibility across studies remains limited, and results should be interpreted as a conceptual evidence map rather than a quantitative synthesis.

## Conclusion
In conclusion, the extensive body of in vitro research has been instrumental in establishing the fundamental mechanisms of nanotoxicity, consistently highlighting the critical role of a nanoparticle’s physicochemical properties. However, a significant gap persists between these cellular findings and their translation to human health outcomes, a challenge compounded by inconsistent experimental models and the complexity of real-world, mixed-material exposures. Bridging this gap requires a continued, multi-faceted approach that integrates compositional analysis of environmental hazards with more standardized in vitro systems and the development of accessible biomarkers. Such efforts are essential for creating evidence-based risk assessments and regulatory frameworks capable of protecting public health in an era of ever-increasing NP exposure.
